text: It means the longest possible run between two consecutive booked halts, commercial halt or technical halt, of Indian Railways. But the train may stop in between this section due to other reasons like signal failure, loco failure, track work etc. This will not be taken in to account while considering the term non-stop run. ==Longest non-stop runs on IR (over 350km)== Here the table is created in the sequence of lengthiest and fastest non stop run. {| class="wikitable sortable" style="font-size: 100%" width= align= |+ |- !! style="background-color:#FFD700" | Sr/No !! style="background- color:#FFD700" | Distance (in km) !! style="background-color:#FFD700" | Running time (hrs:mins) !! style="background-color:#FFD700" | Train Namehttp://www.irfca.org/faq/faq-trivia.html !! style="background- color:#FFD700" | Section |- |1 | 2943 | 44 | Ernakulam–H.Nizamuddin Duronto Express | – |- |2 | 632 |08:05 |New Delhi Allahabad Humsafar Express | - |- |3 | 594 |07:35 |Delhi Sarai Rohila - Yesvantpur Jn. There may be one or more technical halt in-between these two stations. Hence it should not be treated as a non stop run.
